[22] solid solutions, where the tetragonality increases with increasing the PbTiO
high tetragonality has been explained by covalent nature of
O’ bonds which increases the tetragonality [36]. However, high tetragonality in
has been explained by strong coupling between A-site and B-site
structural distortion has not been reported in this system [63].
based particulate composites have been fabricated by taking the magnetic phase NZFO and
morphotropic phase boundary composition of ferroelectric phase BNT-PT
ME response. The lattice parameters of both the magnetic and ferroelectric phases are
modified evident the partial ionic diffusion between two phases. Tetragonality of ferroelectric
phase BNT-PT continuously increases with increasing the NZFO content and finally turns
) phase for x=0.9 by lowering the strain up to 0.7 % to minimize the
energy of the system. The maximum ME coefficient for (1-x)BNT-PT/xNZFO is obtained in
the ferroelectric rich compositions. To get the large ME-coefficient in composite which is
mediated by strain, a composition close to MPB may be chosen for ferroelectric phase
, the structure of which latter may get modified to tetragonal phase.
type ferroelectrics are sintered at lower
omposite formation will be free from unwanted secondary
impurity phases which will provide good ME response. It is obvious that at high sintering
temperatures, the magnetic and ferroelectric phases may react without diffusion of ions. We
have found that the magnetic ordering may be tuned by subsequent composite formation
which turns into superparamagnetic to ferrimagnetic ordering in (1-x)BNT-PT/xNZFO
composite. This work will further encourage the authors to investigate new multiferroic
particulate composites sintered at low temperature by taking various Bi(M
Authors are thankful to Mr. Neeraj Piplani, Marine-India for ME measurements.
